passages.title: The Rise of Urban Farming
passages.passage_text:
In recent years, urban farming has transformed from a niche hobby into a significant movement reshaping city landscapes. Community gardens now dot neighborhoods from Brooklyn to San Francisco, converting vacant lots into productive green spaces. These gardens serve multiple purposes: they provide fresh produce to food deserts, create gathering places for neighbors, and offer educational opportunities for children who might otherwise never see how vegetables grow.

Maya Rodriguez, a coordinator for the Detroit Urban Farming Initiative, has witnessed this transformation firsthand. She recalls when the organization started in 2005 with just three raised beds in an abandoned lot. Today, the initiative manages over forty community gardens across the city, employing twenty full-time staff members and hundreds of volunteers. The gardens produce thousands of pounds of vegetables annually, distributing them free to residents who need them most.

The environmental benefits extend beyond food production. Urban gardens absorb rainwater that would otherwise overwhelm storm drains, reduce the urban heat island effect, and provide habitat for pollinators. Studies have shown that neighborhoods with community gardens experience lower crime rates and increased property values. Residents report feeling more connected to their communities and more invested in neighborhood improvement.

However, challenges remain. Access to land continues to be the primary obstacle, as property owners and city governments often prioritize development over green space. Funding for tools, seeds, and infrastructure requires constant fundraising efforts. Despite these hurdles, the urban farming movement continues to grow, demonstrating that cities can be places not just of consumption, but of cultivation.

questions.context_after: neighborhoods from Brooklyn to San Francisco
questions.notes: Subject 'gardens' is plural, needs plural verb 'dot'. 'Dots' is singular.

questions.context_after: they provide fresh produce to food deserts
questions.notes: Colon is correct to introduce list/explanation of purposes

questions.context_before: Community gardens from Brooklyn to San Francisco
questions.context_after: vacant lots into productive green spaces.
questions.notes: Participial phrase, no comma needed before gerund

questions.context_after: might otherwise never see how vegetables grow.
questions.notes: 'Who' is correct as subject of clause 'who might never see'

questions.context_after: in 2005 with just three raised beds
questions.notes: Simple past 'started' is correct for completed action in 2005

questions.context_before: The initiative manages over forty community gardens
questions.notes: 'Across the city' is concise and not redundant

questions.context_before: producing thousands of pounds of vegetables
questions.notes: 'Annually' is appropriate formal tone for passage

questions.context_before: distributing them free to residents who need them most.
questions.underlined_text: The environmental benefits extend beyond food production.
questions.choice_b: In addition, the environmental benefits extend beyond food production.
questions.choice_c: However, the environmental benefits extend beyond food production.
questions.choice_d: For example, the environmental benefits extend beyond food production.
questions.notes: No transition needed; new paragraph introduces new topic naturally

questions.context_after: rainwater that would otherwise overwhelm storm drains

questions.underlined_text: that would otherwise overwhelm storm drains
questions.context_after: , reduce the urban heat island effect
questions.choice_b: , that would otherwise overwhelm storm drains,
questions.choice_c: which would otherwise overwhelm storm drains,
questions.choice_d: that, would otherwise overwhelm storm drains

questions.context_before: Urban gardens absorb rainwater, reduce the urban heat island effect,
questions.notes: Parallel structure: absorb, reduce, provide (all present tense verbs)

questions.context_before: Studies have shown that neighborhoods with community gardens experience lower crime rates and increased property values.
questions.underlined_text: Residents report feeling more connected to their communities and more invested in neighborhood improvement.
questions.question_stem: Which choice best supports the claim about community benefits?
questions.choice_b: Many residents enjoy gardening as a hobby.
questions.choice_d: Urban farming is popular in many cities.
questions.notes: Sentence directly supports community benefit claims

questions.context_before: Residents report feeling more connected to their communities.
questions.notes: 'However' correctly shows contrast between benefits and challenges

questions.context_before: Despite these hurdles, the urban farming movement continues to grow,
questions.underlined_text: demonstrating that cities can be places not just of consumption, but of cultivation.
questions.question_stem: Which choice provides the most effective conclusion to the passage?
questions.choice_b: showing that gardening is a popular activity.
questions.choice_c: proving that vegetables can grow anywhere.
questions.choice_d: indicating that more research is needed.
questions.notes: Conclusion ties back to transformation theme and broadens significance
